contentrichtext.text: {{Distinguish2|the [[Queen Elizabeth II Bridge (disambiguation)|Queen Elizabeth II Bridge]]}} {{Infobox_Bridge |bridge_name=Queen Elizabeth Bridge |image=Queen Elizabeth Bridge, Windsor (Nancy).JPG |caption= Queen Elizabeth Bridge looking upstream |official_name= |carries= [[A332 road]] |crosses=[[River Thames]] |locale= [[Windsor, Berkshire|Windsor]] |maint= |id= |designer = |design= |material = |spans = |pierswater = |mainspan= |length= |width= |height={{convert|20|ft|6|in|m}}<ref>River Thames Alliance. [http://www.visitthames.co.uk/text.asp?PageId=320 Bridge heights on the River Thames.]</ref> |clearance= |below= |traffic= |open= 1966 |closed= |toll= |map_cue= |map_image= |map_text= |map_width= |coordinates= |lat= |long= }} The '''Queen Elizabeth Bridge''' is a road bridge just to the west of the town of [[Windsor, Berkshire|Windsor]], [[Berkshire]], [[England]]. The Elizabeth bridge carries the [[A332 road|A332]] Windsor By-pass across the [[River Thames]], on the reach between [[Romney Lock]] and [[Boveney Lock]]. The bridge was completed in 1966, and has formed the principal road route between the adjacent towns of Windsor and [[Eton, Berkshire|Eton]] since 1970, when structural cracks in the central [[Windsor Bridge]] forced that bridge's closure to all but [[pedestrian]] traffic, ==See also== *[[Crossings of the River Thames]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * The Royal Windsor website. ''[http://www.thamesweb.co.uk/windsor/windsorbridges/winbridge.html The Town Bridge, Windsor, 1824]''. Retrieved January 16, 2006. {{Start box}} {{River bridge start|River=[[River Thames]]}} {{River bridge line|upstream=[[Summerleaze Footbridge]] (pedestrian) |downstream=[[Windsor Railway Bridge]] (railway) |location =SU956773}} {{End box}} {{UK-bridge-struct-stub}} {{coord|51|29|12|N|0|37|23|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Bridges in Berkshire]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Windsor, Berkshire]] [[Category:Bridges completed in 1966]] [[Category:Bridges across the River Thames]]
